awd_titl_txt: Managing Sustained Online Engagement to Solve Community Problems: An Exploration of Virtual Town Hall Meeting Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Social web technologies have opened unprecedented opportunities for public- and private-sector entities to leverage the collective power of remotely-connected online participants to solve shared problems. However, both practitioners and researchers report that the most challenging issue in open participatory problem-solving initiatives is keeping online participants continuously engaged in a specific project, with sustained interest throughout the entire project cycle. Mindful of the opportunities and challenges of participatory online problem-solving, this study aims to accomplish two research goals: First, based on a theoretical understanding of sustained participatory engagement, we explore managerial and technological innovations that use social web technologies to foster online participants' continuous engagement in shared problem-solving projects. Second, we develop intervention techniques to expedite and sustain the collective ideation process, to enhance the likelihood that genuinely creative and useful problem-solving ideas can be effectively and continuously gathered from participants' ongoing contributions. To achieve these goals, the project pursues a three phased research plan: In the first phase, we seek to identify message-presentation formats that increase the conversion rate of online visitors into contributing participants. In the second phase, we seek to identify user-interface designs that facilitate goal-oriented human-computer interaction and sustain participant engagement over time. In the third phase, we seek to develop and field test brainstorming techniques that leverage social-web interfaces to promote the collaborative ideation process. 

Our proposed study advances practical and theoretical understanding of engagement in online collaboration to solve shared problems. We have built a close partnership with a leading crowdsourcing firm, which provides a participatory technological platform to facilitate collective problem solving in cities, school districts, universities, distributed research communities, etc. This organization has made available data from over 250 real-world problem-solving projects for our analysis. Moreover, the organization has agreed to implement our proposed technological and process interventions in a series of empirical comparative field-tests. These investigations will allow us to develop a theory-driven and evidence-based comprehensive online participatory decision management system that will employ the affordances of social computing to support virtual organizations of all types in maximizing participant engagement in creative collaborative deliberation and problem-solving.

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes

Social web technologies have opened unprecedented opportunities for government and community offices to leverage the collective power of online citizens to discuss and solve various community problems. This phenomenon is called ?community crowdsourcing?. In community crowdsourcing, an online crowd discusses issues such as the beautification of a city?s downtown area or city parks, ways to increase tourism to an area, suggestions to improve public transportation, or developing a future vision for a neighborhood or school district.

However, there are various factors that impede the effective application of online social technologies in practice. Practitioners find that the most challenging issue is to make online citizens continuously engage in a specific community project with sustained interest throughout the entire project cycle. In short, without engagement, there cannot be any meaningful effort to solve problems as a community.

This project followed a three-phased approach to investigate engagement in community crowdsourcing. In the first phase, we used data from a community crowdsourcing provider, MindMixer, to identify the correlation between the crowdsourcing topic?s presentation and instruction format and contribution levels from online citizens. To this end, we first developed a way to determine (calculate) the engagement levels from citizens that are involved in a particular project. Then we analyzed linguistic features and psychological characteristics of the crowdsourcing?s topic description and found a number of significant correlations with participant engagement. These included the length of the topic description, the ratio of inclusive (?we?) words in the description, and the ratio of insight words (?think?, ?know?, ?consider?) in the description. From these findings, recommendations can be formulated about the way in which community crowdsourcing topics need to be presented and described to participants.

In the second phase, we explored how the user interface design in a community crowdsourcing site influences a citizen?s experience and engagement levels. To this end, we developed an experiment in which subjects were asked to participate in a crowdsourcing discussion. Their interactions were recorded, as well as where they looked on the screen through an eye-tracking instrument. The findings show that participants appeared to be more engagement and motivated to make contributions if there was (a) a stronger perception of a balance between their skills and the challenge they were presented with, and (b) if they received feedback on their contributions. From these findings, recommendations can be formulated about the way in which community crowdsourcing topics need to be developed such that they are sufficiently yet not too challenging for the citizens that will be invited to participate.

In the third phase, we developed an advanced studio that simulates ideation and discussion on a community crowdsourcing platform to study a number of factors that we expected to influence engagement levels. Our analyses show strong support for (a) the positive relationship between an individual?s motivation to contribute towards a crowdsourcing discussion and their actual engagement during the discussion and (b) the positive relationship of a person?s interest in the topic and their motivation to contribute. Interestingly, we did not find that a clearer description of the goal of the crowdsourcing discussion resulted in higher engagement levels; the inherent personal interest towards the topic appeared to be a much stronger motivator. From these findings, recommendations can be formulated about how community organizers should work together with the members of the community to determine which topics will be discussed on the community crowdsourcing platform as this is expected to increase the likelihood of higher engagement levels.

The crowdsourcing simulation studio that was prototyped for the third phase of the project, was further developed into a configurable experimentation studio. This studio will allow for future detailed studies into different factors and their correlation with engagement and other important phenomena such as idea creativity, citizen satisfaction, and citizen commitment to outcomes. The researchers are currently preparing a number of such studies for execution.
